titleInfo.title: Assessment of Embedded Perovskite/Mechanoluminescence-Based Sensors for Structural Health Monitoring of Composites

name.namePart: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering

mods:mods.abstract: Advanced composite materials, known for their exceptional tailorability for complex shapes, high strength-to-weight ratio, thermal stability, and corrosion resistance, have transformed engineering structures. However, their anisotropic nature complicates failure prediction and damage detection compared to traditional materials. Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) presents a viable solution, offering real-time structural integrity monitoring through integrated sensors and data processing devices. This dissertation focuses on developing and assessing mechanoluminescence (ML)-perovskite sensors for composite structures. It first delves into the feasibility and performance of planar ML-perovskite sensors, including MAPb(Br0.1I0.9)3 and CsPbBr3 perovskites, which demonstrated sensitivities of 0.47 J-1 and 0.74J-1 respectively, with the capacity to detect impact energies as low as 0.6J and 0.4J. These planar-based ML-perovskite sensors were then compared to the design and fabrication of an innovative fiber-shaped ML-perovskite sensor. This fiber-shaped sensor, showing a promising sensitivity of 1.31J-1 and able to detect energy as low as 1.5J, mitigates the intrusive effect on the composite system's properties by seamlessly integrating into the composite fabric. The ML-perovskite sensors operate on an exciting mechanism where mechanical deformation causes the sensors to emit light. This light emission, or ML, is absorbed by the perovskite layer, which functions as a photodetector. The photodetector converts the light into electrical signals that can be monitored and correlated to potential damage. Notably, these sensors activate only under mechanical stimulation, virtually eliminating false alarms. Rigorous experiments demonstrate their outstanding sensitivity and repeatability, critical attributes for detecting and locating low energy impacts, which can potentially cause barely visible impact damage (BVID), thus playing a crucial role in preventative maintenance and extending the structures' longevity. Detailed discussions on the methods, experiments, and interpretations connected to these sensor performance evaluations substantiate the transformative potential of ML-perovskite sensors in enhancing the safety, reliability, and efficiency of composite structures, thereby paving the way for the development of novel intelligent composite materials and SHM
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Composites, Mechanoluminescence, Perovskite, Sensors, Structural Health Monitoring
Okenwa Okoli, Professor Directing Dissertation; Biwu Ma, University Representative; Tarik Dickens, Committee Member; Zhiyong Liang, Committee Member.
